title: Who Andr s Manuel L pez Obrador AMLO revealed Mexico election win
story: Andrés Manuel López Obrador waves after voting as part of the Mexico presidential electionAndrés Manuel López ObradorAndrés Manuel López Obrador has become the new President of Mexico after winning his third attempt at the presidency and 13 years of pursuing the highest office.Known as AMLO, he has forged through two presidential defeats, two gubernatorial losses and a heart attack in 2013, according to Al Jazeera.Born on November 13, 1953, in the southeastern state of Tabasco, he started his political career in the indigenous affairs bureau for the area in the 1970s. AMLO was then a member of the PRI party, led by President Enrique Pena Nieto, but quit in the late 1980s.After losing the Tabasco governor’s race twice, he staged protests in an attempt to raise his profile during a time in which there was increasing resistance towards the leading party. However, in 2000, AMLO was elected as the mayor of Mexico City as part of the PRD.With his first bid at the presidency in 2006, he promised to ‘put the poor first’, but his critics branded him ‘a danger for Mexico’, likening him to Venezuela’s President Hugo Chavez. The election was decided by a thin margin and López Obrador claimed it had been rigged.          Mexico City's main square, the Zocalo, as Andrés Manuel López Obrador delivers his speechAMLO led protests yet again and declared that he was the legitimate president of Mexico. This led to the former Mayor speaking in villages that had not been visited by political leaders for years.One of his aides, Polimnia Romana Sierra said: ‘He spoke with the same energy under a tree in front of 10 people as he did in the full Zocalo. Nobody works the microphone like him.’He formed a new party, the National Regeneration Movement (MORENA) and by 2015, he was regarded as the next election winner. In addition to this, as the PRI became increasingly involved in corruption scandals, López Obrador also grew in popularity.His wife and fervent feminist, Beatriz Gutierrez, also helped to extend his appeal to female voters in Mexico.          AMLO, accompanied by wife Beatriz Gutierrez Muller, delivers his victory speech in MexicoAndrés Manuel López Obrador's policiesAfter winning the Mexican election, Andrés Manuel López Obrador must now ensure that his promises are fulfilled. Despite critics comparing AMLO to Hugo Chavez and his leftist sympathies could turn Mexico into Venezuela, he took home a landslide victory.According to the BBC, many believe that he shares an authoritarian approach and will ruin the economy, but AMLO has rejected these claims and has said that he will not carry out expropriations and will not seek re-election.However, he has promised to renew contracts awarded by the state oil company Pemex to private companies during the administration of President Enrique Pena Nieto and will check they are not corrupt. He has also vowed to bring economic growth, jobs and social development programmes.‘We will carry out a peaceful transformation, ordered, but profound and even radical, because the word radical comes from root, and what we will do... is, in essence, to root out the corrupt regime,’ he said at one campaign rally.Against what he describes as the ‘power mafia’ of Mexico, he plans to increase scholarships for the young and expand welfare for the elderly, offering ‘good relations’ with the private sector and accusing business leaders of acting ‘like they owned Mexico’.AMLO has also promised to bring peace to the war on drugs, but will not continue the military-led strategy. Notably, he has also said that he would not let Mexico bow down to Trump and asked for ‘friendship’ and ‘mutual respect’ to avoid any trade war.'Soon, very soon, after the victory of our movement, we will defend migrants all over the American continent and the migrants of the world who, by necessity, must abandon their towns to find life in the United States it's a human right we will defend,' Lopez Obrador said in a June speech reported by El Universal.US President Donald Trump congratulated Lopez Obrador in a tweet saying: 'Congratulations to Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador on becoming the next President of Mexico. I look very much forward to working with him. There is much to be done that will benefit both the United States and Mexico!'Who is Morgan Evans? title: US hints FRANCE closest military ally
story: Theresa May told MPs today (pictured) that Britain had the largest defence budget in Europe and the second largest among Nato members           Donald Trump (pictured at the White House with First Lady Melania yesterday) is expected to heap pressure on NATO members to spend more at what could be a bad-tempered summit next week          In a letter to his British counterpart, Defence Secretary Jim Mattis (pictured) suggested the UK might not continue to be a 'global actor' unless funding was increased           Just six NATO countries meet the 2 per cent of GDP target for spending on their military forcesDonald Trump is expected to heap pressure on NATO members to spend more at what could be a bad-tempered summit next week.  In the missive, seen by The Sun, General Mattis told Mr Williamson that Washington is 'concerned' the UK's forces and diplomatic influence are 'at risk of erosion'.He said he wanted Britain to remain America's 'partner of choice' - but added that the French were committed to being 'global actors' alongside the US. Mr Trump will travel to Europe next week for a potentially stormy NATO gathering on July 11-12, before heading to the UK.In the two-page letter, Gen Mattis said 'the credibility of the UK's armed forces' had been crucial in securing its place on the world stage.David Cameron DID ask Barack Obama to warn that Brexit would...Tory Brexit war catches fire as minister demands 'insolent'...Share this articleBut he added: 'I am concerned that your ability to continue to provide this critical military foundation for diplomatic success is at risk of erosion, while together we face a world awash with change.'The UK is committed to meeting the Nato target of spending 2 per cent of GDP on defence, but the US hinted that it wants Mrs May to commit more money.Gen Mattis said: 'A global nation like the UK, with interests and commitments around the world, will require a level of defence spending beyond what we would expect from allies with only regional interests.'Absent a vibrant military arm, world peace and stability would be at further risk.'Highlighting Mr Macron's recent pledge to pump an extra £260billion into defence by 2025, Gen Mattis said: 'As global actors, France and the US have concluded that now is the time to significantly increase our investment in defence.'Other allies are following suit.'          The letter has been leaked as Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson (pictured left with Mrs May and her husband Philip at an Armed Forces Day event over the weekend) lobbies hard for his budget to be expanded    Mr Trump and French president Emmanuel Macron (pictured together at the White House in April) have struck up a close rapportHe stressed that it was 'in the best interest of both our nations for the UK to remain the US partner of choice' but 'in that spirit, the UK will need to invest and maintain robust military capability'.In a reference to the Whitehall rows over funding, Gen Mattis added: 'It is not for me to tell you how to prioritise your domestic spending priorities, but I hope the UK will soon be able to share with us a clear, and fully funded, forward defence blueprint that will allow me to plan our own future engagement with you from a position of strength and confidence.'Downing Street tried to play down the row, insisting Britain has the 'biggest defence budget in Europe and the second biggest in Nato'.‘I would point to the Nato Secretary General following his meeting with the PM where he said he appreciates Britain’s commitment and leadership in the Alliance,' the PM's spokesman said.‘The UK is above the 2 per cent contribution and we have said we will continue to meet that target.‘We, the US and France are close allies and partners willing to take action together in defence of our values.’However, the spokesman refused to state that the UK would continue to have the largest defence budget in Europe.   The week after receiving the letter, Mr Williamson told MPs that US patience over European defence spending was wearing thin.'We can't continue to expect US taxpayers to keep picking up the tab for European defence indefinitely, nor can we expect US patience to last forever,' he said on June 20.The Commons Defence Committee has also called for a significant funding boost, moving the level of defence spending up from 2 per cent to 3 per cent of total GDP.A cash injection on this scale would equate to additional funding of around £20billion a year and bring investment in defence to levels similar to those seen between the end of the Cold War and the mid-1990s.

title: Adorable moment chimpanzee reunited foster parents
story: Limbani was seen drinking through a straw when he hears someone call his name from behind (left) and sees it is his foster parent Jorge (right)The chimp makes sure that his arms are wrapped tightly around the man's neck and his legs around his waist during the loving embrace.Limbani is then quickly distracted after seeing Jorge's wife, Tania, walk into the room. He lets out another excited sound before reaching out to her and giving her a cuddle.The heart-warming footage was posted on Instagram by the Zoological Wildlife Foundation in Miami, who say the couple helped provide the animal with 'around the clock care for the first few months of his life'.Limbani is now staying at the zoo, but regularly sees the couple who raised him when they visit. And even though there can be months between visits, the foundation said the Limbani's reaction is 'always the same' when he is reunited with them.Limbani was rejected after he was born with pneumonia and rejected by his mother.  Limbani could not hide his excitement as he gives Jorge a hug (left). Limbani hit headlines in January when a video of him with a Mastiff dog, named Bruno cuddling went viral.Another video on the Zoo's website shows 'bundle of love' Limbani playing with a golden Tabby tiger cub.

title: Footage shows undertaking Mercedes driver swerving traffic
story: Peter Goodfellow, 36, was jailed for 11 months after the horrifying crash which sent the Mini spinning across three lanes          Video shows Goodfellow undertaking other vehicles as he whizzes down the motorway at dangerous speed.          These dramatic dash-cam images show the moment a speed maniac weaves in and out of motorway traffic at upwards of 100mph, before colliding into a mini at top speedHe was also found to have two bald tyres on his white Mercedes C250 vehicle at the time of the incident on July 19 last year.The smash happened on the M4 carriageway westbound, at the Leigh Delamere services near Chippenham.Goodfellow, of Swindon, Wiltshire, was sentenced at Swindon Crown Court last Friday to 11 months behind bars.Terrifying moment a baby in a buggy rolls off the pavement...Dramatic moment driver, 57, attempts to flee traffic stop...Share this articleHe was also disqualified from driving for 29 months, after which time he will need to retake his driving test. He must pay a victim surcharge of £140.The female driver of the Mini suffered minor injuries.PC Will Ayres, of Wiltshire Police Roads Policing Unit, said: 'Dash cam footage was invaluable in securing this conviction against Goodfellow.          The car hits the mini at top speed and sends it spinning across three lanes of traffic          eter Goodfellow, aged 36 years, was arrested after police arrived at the scene and requested dash-cam footage from nearby cars whose drivers had seen the incident'He is a dangerous driver who had no regard for other road users. This was a busy time of day on a busy stretch of the M4.'Goodfellow put other road users lives at risk, not just by driving at excess speed, but also undertaking vehicles which led to a collision and left an innocent driver with injuries.'Thankfully, these injuries were minor although the incident has no doubt really affected her.'Looking at the dash cam footage provided by a witness, it is so lucky that nobody was more seriously injured.'           The dangerous white Mercedes pictured moments before the incident          The driver of the white Mercedes C250 was also found to have to bald tyres on his car, meaning the grip on the wheels had been excessively worn down, making an accident much more likely

title: Meet BRAVEST football fans England Ramos family cheering Colombia tonight
story: The Ramos family's Colombia flag sticks out in a sea of red and white St George's flags on the Kirby Estate in Bermondsey, south-east London          Sandra Ramos, right, will be cheering on Colombia along with her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three, when they take on England in tonight's big matchFlagging an interest! Football fan who covered his estate in...Share this articleHer eldest son Jean-Paul Jhonnes echoes his mother's passion and he too is hoping that Colombia will win.'I was born here in England and London is my home but I am only supporting Colombia. They are my team. I don't know how it's going to go. It'll be very close, a difficult game.'The England supporters think it will be easy for them, but I don't think it will. Colombia are in a strong position and all the top teams are out. It's been a very unpredictable World Cup.'Jean-Paul, 19, who is currently training at a football academy dreams of making it as a professional player, says despite the rivalry there is a great community spirit on the Kirby Estate, in Bermondsey, south-east London.'Our neighbours are very nice. Most of them will be supporting England but it doesn't matter. They have invited us to watch the match with them on a projector downstairs.'We have invited family and friends to join us so hopefully we will be able to make ourselves heard.'We will be dancing the salsa and the bachata when Colombia score!  Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and his mother Mother Sandra Ramos, 48, will be cheering on Colombia from their second floor flat tonight while all of their neighbours support the Three Lions'It is a very important game. It feels like it is a semi-final match. Whoever wins tonight – Colombia or England – has a good chance to make the final.'Cheering on Colombia will be mother Sandra, 48, her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, her daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, her granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three. Sandra added: 'There is a real community spirit here on the estate. My neighbours are very friendly.'A post-war housing development the heart of Bermondsey, the Kirby Estate has become an a tourist attraction after proud residents strung up 300 St George's flags – and a couple of Colombia tricolours – to mark the 2018 World Cup.School groups and foreign tourists are now flocking to the four-storey blocks to take in the sea of England flags.'There is a real community spirit here on the Kirby Estate,' Chris Dowse, 39, one of the organisers, told MailOnline.'We put letters through everyone's door saying we were going to put England flags on the balconies. Everyone was up for it.'And there are a few other flags as well – Colombian, Brazilian – and that's fine.'People say there's no communities left in London but there absolutely is.'We have people here from lots of different communities, lots of different backgrounds.'We wanted to have a barbecue to celebrate the estate so we put letters through all the doors. I never expected such a response.'I've been properly overwhelmed and humbled by how much everyone's come together.  Everyone on the Kirby Estate tonight will be huddled around a big screen cheering on the Three Lions besides the Ramos family who will be going for Colombia'I grew up in the 80s, back then it was exactly like this, all about the community.'The estate is old fashioned, it's just the way we are. Bermondsey people are known for it.'We've had school kids and tourists come and have a look at all the flags. It's mad.'I want people to come tonight to watch the match. Someone's going be happy and someone's going to be sad but it will be a great night.'

title: Animal outcasts sanctuary Britains wonderfully eccentric farm
story: No room in the barn for this nativity star: For the first few months of his life, Dougal was bottle-fed by members of the public at a farm park in their nativity scene. When he outgrew that and was being sent for slaughter, Manor Farm stepped in. ‘He’s a rascal,’ says Di. ‘Having been given lots of attention, he feels it’s his right to demand fuss from visitors, who are taken by surprise when he head-butts the back of their knees!’          Bullied pig called Simon: Partially-sighted and with deformed front legs, Simon was so terribly bullied by the bigger pigs he shared a sty with at another rescue centre that they asked Manor Farm to take him. ‘He was grossly overweight which didn’t help with his movement problems — if he was a human it’s like he’s walking on his wrists,’ says Di. ‘He’s now lost weight and is enjoying life with his friend Brooke. She chivvies him around all day and I give him strawberries and melon which he loves.’          Jack the VERY stroppy Donkey: Jack was the first non-hen to be taken in by Manor Farm rescue sanctuary after it came into being about seven years ago. ‘We bought the land for it with some money left to me by my Uncle Jack,’ says Di, ‘so when a donkey sanctuary asked me to look after a donkey called Jack it seemed meant to be. The only thing is — he’s nothing like my Uncle Jack who was very gentle whereas donkey Jack is quite stroppy!’Less than a decade ago, Di and Alan were both running businesses from their Nottinghamshire village home.Now they’re also running an animal sanctuary that currently cares for more than 100 farmyard creatures. And not just any creatures. They take in the ones no one else wanted, rejected because they were disabled, had health problems, special needs or simply grew too old.Or, in the case of the many rescued from petting zoos, simply because they grew up. ‘People imagine these animals are living a lovely life in the petting zoo until they die naturally,’ says Di, ‘but that’s not so in the majority of cases.Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Fury at female Kentucky hunter who posted sickening photos...Share this article‘Lambs can be bred out of season to be Christmas attractions to be bottle-fed by visitors but once they’ve grown out of the cute stage, they go into the food chain.’What’s more, they often come to her emaciated, neglected and infested with parasites. Then the battle is on to save their lives. That battle costs Manor Farm Charitable Trust up to £100,000 a year — around a fifth of which are vets’ bills.‘Our vets are constantly challenged by the ageing of our animals,’ Di admits.No wonder — it’s rare farmyard creatures live more than a year or two before going to be slaughtered.          Blind Stevie's a littler wonder: When blind Stevie the Mallard duck came to Manor Farm, they knew he needed a friend to guide him round. ‘I chose a girl called Wanda,’ says Di, ‘because female ducks are louder than the boys and I believed he needed someone noisy to follow around.’ Stevie was found with big scabs over his eyes. ‘We didn’t know at first if he’d been attacked, if they were infected or even if he had eyes. He did — but he was blind.’ Now Wanda’s his guide duck.          Toothless OAP fed on a banana: Life’s left Dolly so scared of human strangers that when summer comes Di can’t call in a shearer —instead she has to do it herself with nail scissors. Dolly, a breeding nanny at a farm park, came to Manor Farm in 2012 when they started neglecting her because she’d become barren. ‘She barely had the strength to hold her head up,’ says Di. ‘But she had an indomitable spirit we could all do with.’ Dolly, who has no teeth, was fattened up with mashed banana and is now in the equivalent of her 90s.          Stumble, duck who live up to his name: Stumble may only have one leg but he’s still the scourge of the female ducks he shares his enclosure with. ‘He’s perfected the ability to jump on to a mate,’ says Di. ‘They all run but they can’t hide from him. Stumble’s leg had to be amputated after getting caught in fishing wire. He’s had a difficult summer because he’s moulted and lost his tail feather and wing tips — which help keep him stable. So he keeps falling over.’ And falling in love.          Goat that costs £3,000 to perk up: Of all the Manor Farm animals, Jo cost the most. So thin when Di rescued him from a petting zoo that he couldn’t hold his neck up, she nursed him back to health in her kitchen. ‘He came up to me as if to say “help me,” ’ she says. Jo was covered in lice and had digestive problems. ‘We nearly lost him several times — he was always the one needing the vet at midnight,’ says Di. But she doesn’t begrudge a penny of the £3,000 he cost. ‘He’s the sweetest creature,’ she says.But it’s not just the vets who have been learning. Di has too. ‘In 2010 I treated myself to four hens as a reward for completing an MA in creative writing and I found it was a slippery slope ,’ she says.A year later, a relative died, leaving her money to buy the six-acre field behind the house. Slowly the brood grew and the dozen or so enclosures now house 64 hens, 27 goats, two donkeys, one pony, two pigs and 30 sheep.Di now employs a full-time member of staff and three part-timers. Every day begins at 6am when she gets the feed ready. It ends at 10.30pm — earlier in winter — when she puts the animals to bed. She also finds time to run her publishing business (and Alan his marketing consultancy firm) which help bankroll Manor Farm.          Ewe with a stiff neck: Born with a twisted neck, Hilda was too deformed to breed and too skinny to slaughter so Di took the tiny ewe in. 'We were told she'd never take to humans,' she eat out of a trough because she'd never seen them before. But within a month she was letting us touch her and gradually she got a lust for life. Now she loves to be cuddled and her tail wags madly like a big dog          A goat the size of a pony: Ronnie, the Anglo Nubian goat, is the size of a Shetland pony. ‘They’re a large breed but he’s a particular giant,’ says Di, ‘and that’s how he ended up here — his elderly owner couldn’t cope with the size of him and was going to have him shot.’ So she did a 135-mile round trip to save him. ‘I knew he was big but even so it was a bit of a shock when I saw him.’Other money comes from corporate and personal donations and the sale of eggs and wool from the animals online. Apart from cash worries, there are other downsides. ‘I’ve had every injury known to man — I’ve lost a nail to a goat horn, been electrocuted by a fence and accidentally injected myself with goat antibiotics,’ says Di.But this pales into insignificance compared to the pain of losing one of their beloved creatures. The sanctuary is full so it’s only with the death of an animal that another can be saved. They come from farm parks, via social media or from other rescue centres.‘It is hard work,’ says Di, ‘but when you see the sheep feeding on the grass and the goats happy in their enclosure, it’s worth it.’          Hen healed in a roasting tray: Buffy the ex-battery hen was doing perfectly well at Manor Farm when she was sat on by another bird and left with a bruised back last winter. ‘One of my biggest joys was that we got Buffy back to health with daily physio,’ says Di. ‘Although I do feel a bit guilty that we kept her in a roasting tray so she could rest her neck on the edge of it. She’s still a bit stiff and walks with a bit of a goose step but is otherwise fine. And she now loves cuddles — every time you pass her she wants you to pick her up.’          Sheep who need a dentist: Dumpy is easy to spot: his teeth have grown so big, his jaw is deformed. ‘But you really couldn’t meet a sweeter sheep,’ says Di. She saved him from the slaughterhouse last year — he was on a trailer bound for it when the farmer’s daughter put out a social media appeal. ‘We all clubbed together to buy him and the farmer said we could have him — as long as we gave the money to Comic Relief,’ says Di. But those teeth keep the dentist busy.Manor Farm Charitable Trust | Lifelong sanctuary for livestock in need

title: World Cup WAG thinks her
story: Flying the flag: England striker Jamie Vardy's wife RebekahHer sharp-shooting husband could fire England into the World Cup quarter-finals tonight.But as the nation holds its breath, striker Jamie Vardy's wife Rebekah is hogging as much of the limelight as she can – claiming her husband's success is partly down to her.The 36-year-old reality TV star has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family.She has also been sharing pictures online of her time with other WAGs, boarding private jets and going on extravagant shopping trips, as well as the inevitable glamorous matchday selfies.Estimates suggest 20million people will watch the game on TV in Britain tonight and 36million pints of beer are expected to be drunk across the country today – 17million in pubs and 19million at home.The British Beer and Pub Association also predicted £25million would be spent on food in pubs today and £30million on meals eaten at home.Meanwhile, the National Grid expects electricity demand to spike by 700 megawatts at half-time – equivalent to 27million fridge doors opening at the same time as fans grab another beer.The grid's director of system operations Duncan Burt said: 'We'll balance supply and demand second by second in real time.'Rebekah Vardy (pictured at England's game against Belgium, left, and on social media, right) has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family and sharing pictures online England face Colombia at 7pm in the 45,000-seater Spartak Stadium in Moscow, with around 4,000 of their fans thought title: The gloriously British summer party
story: Anyone for tennis? Tennis fans soak up the atmosphere at WimbledonTony, who lives just down the road from the Tennis Club — and is already hoarse after shouting 'Taxi! Only two pounds fifty!' from 5.10am — is one of the thousands, many of them enterprising locals, who form the Wimbledon community until a week on Sunday.Most never make it past the hallowed gates of Wimbledon to watch the action on Centre Court, eat overpriced strawberries and drink Pimm's.Instead they spend their (very long) days offering their services to the crowds outside the grounds — selling everything from ice cold water to picnic blankets, Panama hats, designer denim jackets, umbrellas (this week doubling as parasols) and sun cream.'Roger, can I have your headband pleeease!!': Federer gets...Game, sweat and match! Spectators swelter as temperatures...Share this articleChildren write wonky signs on bits of cardboard and sell home-made lemonade. Grannies bake scones and tea loaves. One lady on the main drag from the station is advertising sewing lessons, for goodness sake. A very pale man in a vest, called Ricky — an ice-cream man in his other life — will be here from 7am to 10.30pm, selling iced water at £1 a bottle. 'I'd never sell warm water, ever!' he swears.Some rent out their gardens for parking (£50 a day) or to people running their own stalls.One family have been paid to have their entire front garden transformed in to a Hawaiian paradise, complete with straw gazebo and fake grass, by a sunglasses manufacturer in a bid to 'increase brand awareness'.           Making a small fortune: Tony Finnan, a London black-cab driver, has had his hair trimmed, buzzed and painted bright fluorescent yellow (complete with white seam)Many of the Wimbledon- fortnight community work horrendous hours and make a huge amount of money.Tennis-ball Tony will be here until 10pm tonight, will do 17-hour days for the rest of the tournament and couldn't be happier about it — he earns a small fortune.'It's a trade secret, but it's absolutely worth doing. ABSOLUTELY.' This year he's going to pay for his son Chris's wedding in Santorini. Although I suspect Tony might be here anyway.'I take a fortnight off my usual work and it's like a holiday,' he says. 'It's not as if the people are football hooligans, are they? They're nice people. It's a nice atmosphere.' Because that's the thing about Wimbledon, it is nice — and gloriously British.Yes the Tube is overcrowded, the streets are seething and the sun is doing its best to shrivel the stunning purple, green and white hanging baskets, but somehow no one is shoving or pushing or being remotely irritable.Even the thousands of hot, sweaty people in the vast, snaking mass who queue from 6am each day — first for a queue pass and then, again, to actually enter the grounds — are in good form, and arresting to look at in floral dresses and sunhats, teeny shorts and cropped tops, sport socks, daringly undone shirts, sandals and floppy cricket hats.          Hundreds  of Tennis fans queue in the sweltering heat on Day One of the Wimbeldon Tennis championshipsMeanwhile, the shops in the High Street have gone tennis-mad. Tennis balls and the green, white and purple tournament livery colours are in every windowEd Savitt opened Dropshot, an independent coffee shop, just three weeks ago and is enjoying his 'baptism of fire'. A few doors down, at DeRosier Chocolate &amp Coffee Shop, chocolate tennis balls and chocolate racquets are flying off the shelves.And everywhere you look are dozens of well-heeled and unfailingly polite volunteer stewards sporting bright orange hi-viz jackets, official armbands and a splendid array of Panama hats.There is also an army of professional stewards, which includes Maurice, 68, a retired custody officer. His fluorescent yellow suit is almost too bright to look at as he barks happily at people wandering into the traffic with their noses deep in their phones.Recently widowed Maurice is currently in the middle of summer's stewarding 'season' and loving it.'I've just done Royal Ascot — I did the parking there — 4,000 cars!' Next he's up to Scotland for the European golf tour, followed by a trip to Everest Base Camp in October — something he'd always wanted to do — to commemorate his late wife. His fellow stewards are supporting him financially.He'll be on his feet for 14 hours a day and then home for a long soak in the bath and a huge glass of red wine. 'By the last Sunday I'll be dead on my feet,' he chirps happily. 'I do it every year!'Maurice's spot, a few hundred feet from the Club, is in the epicentre of Joanna Doniger's rental empire, TennisLondon.co.uk, a sort of posh Airbnb for people or corporates who can afford £12,000 for the fortnight, want sleek modern properties and Joanna at their beck and call.This year, the heat has bought fresh challenges, including a glass shower cubicle that exploded in the heat ('luckily no one was in it'), and requests for air-conditioning units and top-of-the-range fans.          This year, the heat has bought fresh challenges for tennis fans waiting in line for tickets None of which is demanded by the thousands camping out this week. There isn't even a shower block in the official camping field.'It's fine,' says Rita, from Melton Mowbray, who is here for the full fortnight with friends Gillian, Anne and Maggie. 'We've got wet wipes and a bucket and we have a strip wash in the loos.'This is their sixth year running and Maggie, 18 yesterday, couldn't think of anywhere she'd prefer to spend her landmark birthday.'It's such fun and everyone is kind and friendly,' she says.Even those who join me at the end of the queue at 12.05pm, where the temperature is 29 degrees and the wait is six hours minimum, are full of the party spirit.No one seems to care that the chances of getting in are minimal. Not even the two ladies I meet who have moved just once (yes, really) since joining the queue at 7.15 this morning.'Time doesn't exist any more,' says Chris, from Nottingham. 'But we're having a very nice time.'More than half the campers aren't even bothering to queue today. They're just enjoying the scene, reading, sunbathing, playing football, listening to music.Natalie, a 33-year-old events organiser is here for the eighth year in a row. She and her friend Lila, are stripped almost off in teeny bikinis and drinking gin and tonics garnished with strawberries.'Every year I want to see Andy Murray here and every year I've failed,' says Natalie.          Wimbledon fortnight is about so much more than the tennis. It is a rite of passage. Pictured, Tatjana Maria in action on day One of the WimbledonNext door but one, the ladies are drinking Prosecco, bought from McClusky's, a corner shop decked out in green and purple. 'The nicest shop in the world!' they trill in unison.Eamon McClusky's family have been running the shop for 62 years, but this promises to be their best yet. He has ordered 50 extra cases of Prosecco, gallons of Pimm's and is overflowing with ice. He will be open from 6am to 11pm and has a 'Wimbledon table' selling everything from instant porridge to sunhats, sunglasses to sandwiches.But not everyone's in it for the money. Over the years, residents have raised tens of thousands for charity by renting out their drives, gardens and even homes.Some rabbis running a popular food stall are raising money for a local Jewish outreach programme.And Jack and Chloe, selling Panama hats at £15 a pop outside a vast house on the main drag, tell me the 'very, very nice' lady who owns the house lets them have the spot in return for a donation to Macmillan Cancer Support.Wimbledon fortnight is about so much more than the tennis. It is a rite of passage. A wonderful two weeks where you can leave your normal life behind, work incredibly hard, laugh a lot, make a tidy nest egg — then spend the rest of the year looking forward to doing it all again next time.

title: Gay cure therapy outlawed
story: Victim: Dean had two so-called exorcisms before accepting his homosexualityThe Government's LGBT (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) action plan – backed by £4.5million from Whitehall – also promises to hold a consultation on making it easier for people to legally change their sex.Ministers originally promised to allow adults to change their gender legally without a doctor's approval last year, but the plan has been repeatedly delayed amid growing criticism.BBC chief stunned as secret staff sex survey reveals 417 of...Eddie Mair hits back at reports he left the BBC after...Share this articleLast night Prime Minister Theresa May said: 'We can be proud that the UK is a world leader in advancing LGBT rights, but the overwhelming response to our survey has shone a light on the many areas where we can improve the lives of LGBT people.'I was struck by just how many respondents said they cannot be open about their sexual orientation or avoid holding hands with their partner in public for fear of a negative reaction.'No one should ever have to hide who they are or who they love. This LGBT action plan will set out concrete steps to deliver real and lasting change across society, from health and education to tackling discrimination and addressing the burning injustices that LGBT people face.'The action plan said the Government will consider 'all legislative and non-legislative options' to prohibit 'promoting, offering or conducting conversion therapy'.It said: 'We will act so that LGBT people feel safe in their own homes and in their communities. Our survey shows that many LGBT people do not report hate incidents they experience and that the abhorrent practice of conversion therapy is still alive in our country.

title: Theresa Mays opaque glass old municipal lavatory
story: As superglue drips, so did we all sit through another of Theresa May's parliamentary turns on Brexit. Within seconds, the House was rigidWords may be uttered but they mean – and are designed to mean – nothing. To be so consistently uninformative, so cryptic, as opaque as the glass in an old municipal lavatory, is actually a feat.'We have put forward proposals,' she said about her negotiations with Brussels. 'And we will put forward further proposals.' Er, great.Around the world, political analysts place raw May verbiage into their petri dishes. They crouch over the most modern microscopes to try to detect meaning in these tiny off-cuts. What does the British Prime Minister mean? Which way is she leaning? To British independence? Or to capitulation to the forces of Brussels, Barnier and subsidy-junkie multinationals which want the status quo?These brilliant, white-coated eggheads look up from their instruments, pinkish roundels surrounding their eyes, their Einstein hairdos askew, and for a nanosecond they may think they have a solution.           Officially the Prime Minister was at the despatch box to talk about last week's EU summit but most MPs asked her about Brexit. The optimistic foolsThey sense that Mrs May has let slip a tiny hint as to her true intentions. But then they look again and they wearily have to report to their bosses, no, sorry, we simply haven't a clue what the old girl is saying. She is so comprehensively, ingeniously, glue-ishly uncommunicative.Listening to the shipping forecast in Finnish, back to front, might be more informative.He mentioned fears of a beer drought... MPs gasped: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament Boris got away without a scrape on his bodywork: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in ParliamentJust tragic! Gothic opera without a decent tune, QUENTIN LETTS reviews The Turn of the Screw Open mutiny from our wet-as-celery Business bloke: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament QUENTIN LETTS: Meet the faint-hearted, Europhile Business Secretary who spoke with Airbus before the company threatened to quit the UK Wonder bard: QUENTIN LETTS says Cole Porter's musical takes a while to warm up, but once it does it's Too Darn HotWould bouncy Bercow go now? Would he heck: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament QUENTIN LETTS: Grieve pulled on the khazi chain... yank, clang, sploshHunt and Javid, the decisive duo taking on procrastinating Mrs May and the pfafferati: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in ParliamentCertain theories sometimes take hold, as started to happen yesterday – this time claiming that she was about to buckle to her wetly pro-Brussels civil servant, Olly Robbins, who has been trying to bypass the elected David Davis at the Brexit department. Robbins is credited (I am sure without any truth) with trying to tweak the minutes from Whitehall meetings to prevent assurances from Mrs May to Mr Davis being recorded by Civil Service note-takers.Such rumours about Mrs May's Brexit intentions usually begin with newspaper reports or internet gossip and soon become received wisdom that one side or the other in the Brexit battle is going to take a whack on the schnozzle.Mrs May is eventually asked about the rumour and reverts to a worn formula of words which may or may not mean 'nothing has changed'. Yesterday she was asked if she would go for a Norway-style deal, if she would accept the EEA option, if she would let European courts have a say on our laws after Brexit, and much else besides.'There has been much jocularity,' she said, 'about the phrase 'Brexit means Brexit' – but it does mean Brexit.' See? This remark actually drew laughter, it was so classically May-ish.She reiterated that she wanted to do independent British trade deals, to control our own borders and laws, yet still trade with the EU. She says this almost every time she is on parade.           Mrs May is eventually asked about the rumour and reverts to a worn formula of words which may or may not mean 'nothing has changed'Remainers say she cannot possibly achieve all these things, and they wonder how breakfast waiters ever get Mrs May to opt between the kippers and the eggs benedict.She was told she must finally make a choice on Brexit. 'People are fed up with not just Brexit but also with fudge,' hollered Anna Soubry (Con, Broxtowe). Other Europhiles such as Nicky Morgan (Con, Loughborough) and Vicky Ford (Con, Chelmsford) wanted Mrs May to reach a 'pragmatic and practical Brexit' deal – the new euphemism for a cave-in. Mrs May hosed down their pleas with wordy foam.She responded the same way when Leavers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg (Con, NE Somerset) and Bill Cash (Con, Stone) sought nervous reassurances.Short-term forecast: continued, maddening fog.

title: A fifth MPs second job side
story: One in five MPs holds down a second job on the side, the Westminster watchdog has revealedDozens more MPs earn vast sums from irregular work such as speaking engagements, appearing on TV and writing newspaper columns.The committee demanded that Parliament's code of conduct be rewritten to make it clear that MPs should only be allowed to take posts which do not 'compromise their principal role as an MP'.'Gay cure' therapy will be outlawed: Prime Minister Theresa...Boris Johnson BACKS Jacob Rees-Mogg's threats to Theresa May...Share this articleIt said they should only take an outside position with hours within 'reasonable limits', although it did not spell out what this should be. It also recommended that MPs should be banned from working for lobbying firms.The report said: 'A majority of MPs do not hold remunerated outside interests, and a number hold outside interests that can be considered within 'reasonable limits'. However, where a small number of iniduals have taken up outside interests beyond what might be considered reasonable, it risks undermining trust in Parliament and Parliamentarians.'          No MPs are named in the report, but an investigation earlier this year found that the highest paid was Nadhim Zahawi (pictured), the Tory MP for Stratford-on-AvonThe committee said former MPs should register new jobs which put them into contact with ministers. This is designed to tackle the revolving door scandal, where ex-MPs exploit their political contacts in private sector jobs.However, the recommendations need to be passed by Parliament and could simply be rejected.No MPs are named in the report, but an investigation earlier this year found that the highest paid was Nadhim Zahawi, the Tory MP for Stratford-on-Avon.Mr Zahawi, who was chief strategy officer at Gulf Keystone Petroleum, reported outside earnings which were the equivalent of an annual salary of £765,000. He resigned in January after being made Minister for Children and Families.The committee's report found that 18.5 per cent of the 643 MPs have regular, paid outside commitments. In total, they earned £3.35million last year – an average of £28,000 each.

title: England fans shake nerves rally Three Lions
story: Former England striker turned pundit Michael Owen perfectly summed up the nation's logic defying belief, writing: 'we've been beat by the only decent team we've faced yet the country is convinced we can win the World Cup... and I'm starting to believe too!'Fans have already endured a roller coaster of emotions having gone from apathy to elation and then disappointment as England's World Cup has progressed so far - but a victory over Colombia would see a tidal wave of excitement sweep the nation as the draw opens up extremely favourably for England.  Expectations had been low for the England squad following more than a decade of tournament failure, but a barnstorming win over minnows Panama wowed fans and commentators alike - as the nation's new golden boy Harry Kane netted three goals for himself on the way to a 6-1 route. 'Rake thin' Thai boys and their football coach found alive...Man walks from a burning building with skin hanging off his...Share this articleAnd after finishing second in the group stage - following a 1-0 defeat to Belgium, where both sides fielded weakened teams - fans are now hoping to get the show back on the road and land a quarter final place  against one of Switzerland or Sweden, who are set to do battle in the afternoon fixture.One-time England starlet turned pundit Owen perfectly summed up the nation's mindset, writing: 'We've been beaten by the only decent team we've faced yet the country is convinced we can win the World Cup... and I'm starting to believe too!' Hilarious tweets show how many have woken up this morning feeling hopeful but scared. One woman pondered: 'Is it okay if I phone in sick because I am so nervous?'           One fan wrote shortly after 7am: 'I can't work out whether I'm excited or nervous, all I know is I need a fag and a I need beer and I haven't had either in years.'Iain Shepherd posted: 'Feeling sick with worry and nerves and the game isn't on for another 12 hours. It's a huge chance. Come on England!' While Braden Valles wrote: 'I am literally only focused on the match tonight now, not going to lie.'And another said: 'Sitting here eating my breakfast and now on simulation number 167 of how tonight's game could pan out.'            Fans have already endured a roller coaster of emotions having gone from apathy to elation and then disappointment as England's World Cup has progressed so far - but a victory over Colombia would see a tidal wave of excitement sweep the nation as the draw opens up extremely favourably for England          The last time the two sides met was back in 2005 for a friendly where England won 3-2Gareth Southgate's team must get past the impressive Colombians who topped a difficult group containing Japan, Poland and Senegal. The last time the two sides met was back in 2005 for a friendly where England won 3-2. They haven't met competitively since 1998 where David Beckham and Darren Anderton gave the Three Lions a comfortable 2-0 win at the World Cup in France. But a strong squad built around the Real Madrid star man Rodriguez, who shot to fame at the last World Cup in Brazil as the tournament's top goal scorer, will prove a heady task for England's young side. Such is the anticipation that in Parliament, the Cabinet has informed whips to install TVs in the Commons smoking rooms to persuade MPs to stay and vote.            Popular pundit and former England and Arsenal hero Ian Wright shared a picture of himself being embraced by manager Southgate during their playing days. Wright geed up his followers with a tweet encouraging everyone to get behind the Three Lions. Popular pundit and former England and Arsenal hero Ian Wright shared a picture of himself being embraced by manager Southgate during their playing days. Wright geed up his followers with a tweet encouraging everyone to get behind the Three Lions.       Fans have been sharing their nerves ahead of the fixture tonight

title: Allies Jacob Rees Mogg sound PR firms Tory leadership bid
story: Allies of Jacob Rees-Mogg (pictured) apparently sought advice from PR experts on how to exploit the Brexiteer's cult following among activists          The efforts come as Theresa May (pictured in the Commons last night) faces a potentially decisive battle with her own Cabinet over future relations with the EUMr Rees-Mogg has positioned himself as the champion of 'clean' Brexit, delivering a stark public warning to Mrs May yesterday that breaking 'red lines' in negotiations could collapse her administration.The intervention by the Old Etonian and investment banker brought a furious response from some ministers who branded him 'insolent' and 'ideological' - although Boris Johnson defended his right to speak out.The North East Somerset MP has become an unlikely hit with grassroots activists for his traditional Conservative views and 'young fogey' style.He currently heads the 60-strong group of Eurosceptic Conservative MPs.Theresa May's as opaque as the glass in an old municipal...Share this articleHowever, so-called 'Moggmentum' movement appears to have cooled amid a backlash over the devout Catholic's hardline views on abortion and gay marriage.A source told The Times that PR firms had been approached. 'They were asked to explain how, if Jacob was speaking at a university, they would go about maximising the publicity and harvesting the greatest number of supporters who could later be converted into voting Tory members,' the source said.Veteran Tory MP Sir Bill Cash, a close friend of Mr Rees-Mogg, said he 'didn't recognise' a claim that he had been involved in interviewing PR firms and raising financial backing.           Ministers attacked Mr Rees-Mogg over his Brexit stance yesterday, with Alistair Burt and Sir Alan Duncan among those who accused him of 'lecturing and threatening' the PM          Fellow minister Richard Harrington also waded into the row to condemn Mr Rees-Mogg's comments          Senior Tory MP Sir Nicholas Soames said Mr Rees-Mogg should 'shut up' and accused him of making empty threats - saying he was 'all gong and no dinner' Mr Rees-Mogg has laughed off the idea of becoming leader and insists he is unaware of any fledgling campaign.'I have absolutely no knowledge of this,' he said. Yesterday there were reports that backers of Mr Rees-Mogg had raised a £750,000 war chest in case there is a leadership contest.A pro-Brexit MP has teamed up with a former UKIP member to assemble a fighting fund, according to the Express.A senior Tory said: 'We have given up on Theresa May and the current Cabinet. The membership love Jacob.'

title: Extraordinary honeymoon demands super rich revealed
story: Ultra-rich couples' demands range from the bizzare to the utterly ludicrous — including one man's £80,000 payment to carpet his yacht so his wife could walk in stilettos'One newlywed visiting the Seychelles would drink only Fiji water a crate was duly flown in to supply her nightly.'Another luxury travel firm based in the UK, Red Savannah, arranged to special delivery of a Cartier bracelet to a bride on her honeymoon in Dubain. As the couple sat down to dinner, her attention was caught by a er in an aquarium who was swimming towards her, waving. The er then produced a sign that read 'look next to your plate'.          The same company even arranged for one couple to spend the night in Louis XIV's Versailles bedBut some requests have been even more demanding. Mr Presser wrote: 'For a five-night trip, one television actress paid $40,000 to have her hotel bathroom's granite sink lifted 7in — all so she wouldn't have to bend over when washing her face.Another couple who travelled to St Lucia discovered the resort held a strict first-come-first-served beach lounger policy. You're not rich until you have at least $25 MILLION,...Meghan's mum gets the royal treatment as she flies into...Tears, tirades and tantrums: The explosive first interview...Share this article    One pop star demanded fresh dragon fruit while holidaying in Iceland, meaning the firm had to supply the Icelandic government with fruit for weeks before being given customs approval A pop star demanded fresh dragon fruit while holidaying in Iceland. The firm had to supply the Icelandic government with fruit for weeks before they were given customs approval.One client who wanted specific cuts of meat from his favourite butcher had the firm bring the meat through airport security in chilled cases all the way to the hotel kitchen. Another even supplied a paint swatch showing exactly how rare he wanted his steak cooked.A man spent $80,000 to have his yacht carpeted so his wife could walk around the deck in stilettos. After dogs, the second most requested pet are birds of prey. Airlines such as Emirates allow them on flights without a handler — but only in first class.But rather than choosing to get up earlier to reserve a spot in the sun, the couple actually attempted to purchase the beach. Their offer was refused and instead an agent had to wake early every morning to reserve their sun loungers. One couple dream Caribbean honeymoon was nearly shattered by a storm that washed away the beach front.They paid the firm £50,000 to have sand from another beach driven over in trucks so they could sunbathe.           After dogs, the second most requested pet are birds of prey. Airlines such as Emirates allow them on flights without a handler — but only in first classThe same company even arranged for one couple to spend the night in Louis XIV's Versailles bed.'It was quite an expensive and special arrangement,' said president Jack Ezon. And other couples' getaways simply would not be complete without the company of their pets. The fork out thousands for everything from extra bedrooms, massages, gourmet food and cusom-built furniture for their furry friends. But even with their vast sums of money, rich and found marriages often break down before they take off. One bride walked out on the groom after find he had still not give up his 'illicit habits'. After she had flown off, he asked for some 'professional company' that was illegal in the Males — so he was flown Bankok and set up with a 'nightlife guide'.

title: Toddler gets hand jammed lift playing doors mother watches on
story: The boy's mother was standing right next to him when he got his hand trapped in the lift'This is like Mao’s China': Piers Morgan compares schools...Eddie Mair hits back at reports he left the BBC after...Trump threatens WTO, saying the U.S. will respond if it...Remains of burial horses from 2,700 years ago are found in...Share this articleThe boy was seen playing with the buttons and jumping around in the lift prior to the accident, with his mother standing right next to him.She did not appear to stop him playing  in the lift.The toddler then placed his right hand on the doors and they suddenly opened, taking his hand into the side panel with it and snagging his fingers. The desperate mother immediately squatted down and tried to pull her son's hand out but his fingers remained firmly jammed between the lift wall and the door, which was half open.   The boy was seen playing with the buttons and jumping around in the lift prior to the accident          The desperate mother immediately squatted down and tried to pull her son's hand out but his fingers remained firmly jammed between the lift wall and the door, which was half open  A passer-by rushed to their aid while the mother repeatedly pressed the alarm buttonA passer-by rushed to their aid while the mother repeatedly pressed the alarm button.Chinese net users have blamed the mother's apparent negligence for the accident. 'This mother does not deserve sympathy,' one said. title: Boardmaster Festival medics ignored teenagers pleas help
story: Pictured: George Zographou tragically died after contracting meningitis b A teenager died after festival medics failed to pick up on the signs of meningitis and left him on a tent floor in a coma.George Zographou, 18, was shaking and vomiting but doctors told his parents his illness wasn't serious with his mother asked to pay for a taxi to take him to hospital.But the sixth form student went into cardiac arrest on the tent floor and died days later in hospital.He had only just completed his A levels at a well-regarded college in his home city of Bristol. A government report released yesterday revealed how George's pleas for help fell on deaf ears. He arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill.The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legs. He could only crawl on his hands and knees, the report read, and was not able to walk without help.   Security teams called the medics, who took him to the tent on a buggy. He continued to throw up, had low blood pressure and an increased heart rate.          George arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill, spending his first night in his tent throwing up His mother called the medics and explained his heart rate was too high, and he was given morphine. A rash developed on his left foot, and the young man was diagnosed with dehydration and a stress fracture.George became agitated, and he was put on the floor. The report read: 'His mum, via the phone, asked that he be sent to hospital. The doctor said it was not an emergency so he would need to go in a taxi and pay.'Students and irresponsible landlords leave mountains of...'Sick with worry and nerves and the game isn't on for...'He's expecting them to walk through the door': Boy, four,...WAGs can help England win the World Cup: Rebekah Vardy says...Share this articleShe pleaded for George to be taken to hospital, but the medics did not budge. Worried, George's parents drove down to Cornwall to bring him to hospital themselves, he was moved to a welfare tent.By that point, George had become 'agitated and aggressive' and lost consciousness. Staff were told to provide one-on-one observation, and they thought he had fallen asleep.'George was in fact in a coma and soon after went into cardiac arrest,' the working group's report read. 'He was blue lighted to hospital and on life support for five days.' His tragic case has been highlighted in a government report released yesterday.          The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legsHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parents and also the family of Izzy Gentry, who also died after her meningitis was not diagnosed quickly enough. The report intends to raise awareness about the deadly illness and help medical staff and volunteers at festivals and mass gatherings to be able to recognise the signs  early. Izzy was only 16 years old when she was sent home from the Bristol Royal Infirmary with gastroenteritis instead of meningitis. The coroner ruled her death had been contributed to by neglect.After meeting the families, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised and commissioned the report, which makes 12 recommendations. It includes listening to parents, better care at festivals and more awareness to the illness.          Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parentsIzzy complained of headaches and not feeling well. There had been a meningitis case two weeks earlier at St Brendan's Sixth Form College, where both she and Geroge were pupils.Izzy developed a high temperature, became lethargic and soon started vomiting and developed neck and limb pain.She was taken by ambulance to the BRI, with paramedics warning of potential sepsis and meningitis.At triage, the doctor made an initial examination and diagnosed her with gastroenteritis, sending her home with fluids and painkillers, making no reference to meningitis.At home, she worsened and suffered a fit, and she was rushed back to hospital. Izzy fell unconscious by the time she got to A&ampE and doctors said it was serious and she was taken into intensive care. Less than half an hour later, she was diagnosed with meningitis.Izzy was stabilised, but her condition got worse and her organs shut down. An inquest concluded her death had been contributed by neglect.The report made 12 recommendations, including asking all medical staff and volunteers at festivals to to know the signs of meningitis.Those staff and volunteers need to checked through by the Care Quality Commision (CQC) and communication also needs to be improved.The working group also wants Public Health England to review its leaflets on vaccinations and meningitis.

title: Greek athletes olive oil traditional wrestling rivals hands rivals trousers
story: Each one-on-one battle can take from five seconds, to up to 40 minutes including added time, depending on strategy and tactics. The best way to succeed is to avoid the slippery torsos, and aim for fellow competitors’ trousers, called kismet          Limbering up before going onto the grassed wrestling zone, these competitors have already been covered in olive oil for the traditional event, which dates back two millennia. Oil wrestling is believed to be the closest to ancient Greek wrestling in style. However, in ancient times, the Greeks would have competed naked, as they did in all sports          Bare torso, and with bare feet, this wrestler is donning thick trousers made of calfskin leather. Some wrestlers also wear jeans. The trousers the men wear are made of thick leather in a traditional design called kisbet. In recent years manufacturers have changed from traditional buffalo to calfskin. While durable, sometimes they are torn apart in the fighting          Wrestlers covered in olive oil fight in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition in the northern Greek village of Sochos. Muscular men walk around the lawn, which is turned into a wrestling ring, to the tune of traditional music, with their torsos slathered in olive oil for the yearly festival that blends the traditions of ancient Greece and more modern times          Fights take place simultaneously in a large field, and unlike most combat sports there is no set field or arena. The wrestlers are free to roam around as the fight takes them, and are typically followed by a referee. Unlike Greco-Roman wrestling, which relies heavily on technical ability, oil wrestling is more a test of endurance          In tears: a wrestler covered in olive oil reacts after taking part in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition in the northern Greek village of Sochos. The oil makes it harder for the wrestler to grip opponents, so this type of combat needs a certain strategy, besides strength, to succeed          Oil wrestling is one of the oldest sports in the world, which dates back to the ancient city of Babylon but is still practiced across Turkey and in northern parts of Greece. There is no score in the event. The winner is the man who manages to throw his opponent onto the ground so that his shoulders touch the soil          Prior to the matches, wrestlers cover their bodies in olive oil as they prepare to compete in the event. It is not unusual for competitors to oil one another, above, to show mutual respect. The traditional sport of oil wrestling in Greece has continued from generation to generation          Spectators watch as wrestlers covered in oil take part in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition, in the northern Greek village of Sochos. Fights take place simultaneously in a large field, and unlike most combat sports there is no set field or arena. title: Boardmaster Festival medics ignored teenagers pleas help
story: Pictured: George Zographou tragically died after contracting meningitis b A teenager died after festival medics failed to pick up on the signs of meningitis and left him on a tent floor in a coma.George Zographou, 18, was shaking and vomiting but doctors told his parents his illness wasn't serious with his mother asked to pay for a taxi to take him to hospital.But the sixth form student went into cardiac arrest on the tent floor and died days later in hospital.He had only just completed his A levels at a well-regarded college in his home city of Bristol. A government report released yesterday revealed how George's pleas for help fell on deaf ears. He arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill.The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legs. He could only crawl on his hands and knees, the report read, and was not able to walk without help.   Security teams called the medics, who took him to the tent on a buggy. He continued to throw up, had low blood pressure and an increased heart rate.          George arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill, spending his first night in his tent throwing up His mother called the medics and explained his heart rate was too high, and he was given morphine. A rash developed on his left foot, and the young man was diagnosed with dehydration and a stress fracture.George became agitated, and he was put on the floor. The report read: 'His mum, via the phone, asked that he be sent to hospital. The doctor said it was not an emergency so he would need to go in a taxi and pay.'Students and irresponsible landlords leave mountains of...'Sick with worry and nerves and the game isn't on for...'He's expecting them to walk through the door': Boy, four,...WAGs can help England win the World Cup: Rebekah Vardy says...Share this articleShe pleaded for George to be taken to hospital, but the medics did not budge. Worried, George's parents drove down to Cornwall to bring him to hospital themselves, he was moved to a welfare tent.By that point, George had become 'agitated and aggressive' and lost consciousness. Staff were told to provide one-on-one observation, and they thought he had fallen asleep.'George was in fact in a coma and soon after went into cardiac arrest,' the working group's report read. 'He was blue lighted to hospital and on life support for five days.' His tragic case has been highlighted in a government report released yesterday.          The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legsHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parents and also the family of Izzy Gentry, who also died after her meningitis was not diagnosed quickly enough. The report intends to raise awareness about the deadly illness and help medical staff and volunteers at festivals and mass gatherings to be able to recognise the signs  early. Izzy was only 16 years old when she was sent home from the Bristol Royal Infirmary with gastroenteritis instead of meningitis. The coroner ruled her death had been contributed to by neglect.After meeting the families, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised and commissioned the report, which makes 12 recommendations. It includes listening to parents, better care at festivals and more awareness to the illness.          Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parentsIzzy complained of headaches and not feeling well. There had been a meningitis case two weeks earlier at St Brendan's Sixth Form College, where both she and Geroge were pupils.Izzy developed a high temperature, became lethargic and soon started vomiting and developed neck and limb pain.She was taken by ambulance to the BRI, with paramedics warning of potential sepsis and meningitis.At triage, the doctor made an initial examination and diagnosed her with gastroenteritis, sending her home with fluids and painkillers, making no reference to meningitis.At home, she worsened and suffered a fit, and she was rushed back to hospital. Izzy fell unconscious by the time she got to A&ampE and doctors said it was serious and she was taken into intensive care. Less than half an hour later, she was diagnosed with meningitis.Izzy was stabilised, but her condition got worse and her organs shut down. An inquest concluded her death had been contributed by neglect.The report made 12 recommendations, including asking all medical staff and volunteers at festivals to to know the signs of meningitis.Those staff and volunteers need to checked through by the Care Quality Commision (CQC) and communication also needs to be improved.The working group also wants Public Health England to review its leaflets on vaccinations and meningitis.

title: water company bosses bonuses ofwat payouts
story: Ofwat tells industry to link payouts to performance or face curbs in futureExcessive payouts for the bosses of England’s privatised water companies and their investors have damaged customer trust and could be curbed in future, the industry watchdog has said. Warning of intervention powers over executive pay and idends, Ofwat said it would run an assessment over the winter to check whether water companies were doing enough to link performance-related pay to customer delivery. Firms will submit their business plans, including their pay and idend policies, to the regulator this September.Rachel Fletcher, the watchdog’s chief executive, said: “The decisions some water companies have made on idends, financial structures and top executive pay have damaged customer trust.”She added that Ofwat would strengthen the incentive on companies to improve their performance for customers, while cutting the rewards that come from financial engineering – which involves firms ratcheting up their debts and using complex corporate structures.“This is an important step in making sure water companies put customers’ interests and those of future generations, at the heart of all the decisions they take,” she said.Water industry bosses faced sharp criticism last month after the GMB trade union found they had banked £58m in pay and benefits over the last five years while customers have faced above-inflation rises in their water bills.The move from Ofwat also comes after the environment secretary, Michael Gove, attacked water companies for paying their bosses large salaries and huge idends to shareholders while contributing little or no tax.Labour has promised to bring water companies back into public ownership to save households money, amid rising public anger over pay and poor performance.Ofwat issued a damning report last month, finding that water companies badly let down their customers during the “beast from the east” weather earlier this year. More than 200,000 households were cut off, yet compensation payouts totalled only £7m.
